4.29.text:
Here we go.
Hello, hello, everyone.

7.29.text:
Thank you for joining us, and thank
you to the organizers for inviting us.

15.04.text:
I'm an associate director of instructional
design here at Stanford University.

19.82.text:
I work for the office of the vice
provost for teaching and learning.

22.38.text:
And I'm accompanied here by my colleague,
Ken Ligda, who is going to talk next.

28.98.text:
He's also an associate director for
instructional design.

32.38.text:
We're also fortunate to have with
us Julio Grata and Craig Sapp.

37.52.text:
They wrote some of the software
that we're going to spotlight in

44.45.text:
So we're gonna talk about a couple
of courses that the vice provost for

47.98.text:
teaching and learning has put out through
its online portal Stanford Online.

53.71.text:
The first course is Defining
the String Quartet: Haydn.

58.64.text:
This is a self paced MOOC that
just came out about a month ago.

66.22.text:
It's a collaboration
between professor of music,

69.94.text:
Stephen Hinton and the ensemble in
residence, the St Lawrence String Quartet.

76.50.text:
So this course features conversations
between Stephen and the Quartet.

81.95.text:
Stephen talks about the genre
of the string quartet and

85.47.text: how it was developed by Haydn.

88.31.text:
He might talk about a certain form or
gesture.

93.18.text:
it was beautifully shot by
our team back here actually.

98.38.text:
They did a great job in our
beautiful new Bing Concert Hall.

101.75.text:
And this course featured
a challenge which many MOOCs

106.86.text:
present to instructional
designers which is,

111.39.text:
how do you present to a very
broad audience using this medium.

117.88.text:
So Stephen wanted to really be able
to dig into the meat of the matter.

121.39.text:
He wanted to be able to
get into the analysis,

124.83.text: to talk deeply about the history.

127.15.text:
But he also didn't want to alienate
learners who didn't know how to

130.66.text:
read music, who had no experience
whatsoever with music.

136.50.text: So we had a number of different ideas for

139.34.text:
how to tackle this challenge which
I'm going to present to you.

143.58.text: The first one was to use layered content.

148.50.text:
So some of the content in the course
is quite advanced, some of it is

153.01.text:
fairly basic, and so there's a little
bit of something there for everybody.

157.97.text:
There are also two types of statement of
accomplishment that students can earn.

163.06.text:
There's a basic statement
of accomplishment and

166.14.text:
there's an advanced
statement of accomplishment.

168.93.text:
Corresponding to these two statements,
there are two different types of problems

174.05.text:
that we marked with a single eighth
note and a double eighth note.

181.21.text:
So if you do only the single eighth note
problems, you can earn a basic statement.

185.28.text:
And if you do the double eighth note
problems, you can earn the advanced one.

190.63.text:
We wanted to make sure though,
even still that students who

195.49.text:
didn't know how to read music could
access as much of the course as possible.

200.83.text:
And so we actually have a lot of
messaging in the course encouraging

204.26.text:
them to try the double
eighth note problems

206.70.text:
even if they don't read music because
a lot of them actually are accessible, and

210.79.text:
we also have some other
software solutions for this.

216.80.text:
So Solution #2 is dynamic scores or
interactive scores.

223.34.text:
So you're all familiar with
the Open edX platform, and you

227.87.text:
know how it has the scrolling captions on
the side that highlight what's being said.

232.48.text:
Well, Craig here designed a platform
that does the same thing, but for music.

237.48.text:
So you've got the music playing and
there's a scrolling score and

240.93.text:
it highlights the notes
that are being played.

243.41.text: So I'm going to show you a little clip.

263.24.text:
So you can see there that as a note is
played, it gets highlighted in red.

269.58.text: Much like on the Open edX platform,

273.11.text:
you can also click on a specific note and
have it jump there.

276.87.text: So let me show you how that works.

279.14.text: You'll see the mouse click in a minute.

292.80.text:
Now there've already been some comments
in the discussion forum about this tool.

298.45.text:
People are saying, hey, this is pretty
nifty, and I don't know how to read music

302.32.text:
but I actually feel like I get
a sense now of what those dots and

305.61.text:
lines mean, based on watching
the score as I listened to the music.

311.00.text:
And now since we have some developers in
the audience, I thought it would be nice

314.22.text:
to have Craig come up on stage and tell
you a little bit about how he did this.

319.02.text:
So Craig is a consulting assistant
professor in the Center for

323.07.text:
Computer Assisted Research and
the Humanities.

326.34.text:
>> Yeah.
So I'll just give a very brief overview

328.35.text:
and if people wanna have more
detail afterwards they can come and

332.68.text:
So here's kind of the basic
overview of how it works.

336.61.text:
So I work with HTML5 audio and
video interface with a little

341.75.text:
loop that runs whenever you
start playing the video and

346.48.text:
then it keeps track of kind of
a table between the score time and

351.82.text: the physical time and the performance.

355.34.text:
And then, depending on what time,
if it's time for something to happen,

361.31.text:
like turning on our note off in
the notation, it'll go to the <svg> and

367.09.text:
put in little class tags to turn things
on or remove them to turn them off.

372.92.text:
So the core of the system is the alignment
between the audio and the notation.

377.58.text:
So I do analysis on performance
analysis of piano pieces.

385.30.text:
And so
I've written some audio mark up tools for

389.55.text:
a program called Sonic Visualizer,
which is an annotation tool for audio.

393.92.text:
There's also been, I've seen a few online
web interfaces that do similar things,

399.60.text:
but this is more for scientific research,
so I can get very accurately alignment.

406.40.text:
So what I do is I basically have,
the orange thing is the audio wave form.

411.87.text:
The purple vertical lines
are where I'm putting my marks.

414.76.text:
And then I label which measure and
which beat.

418.00.text:
And then this black kind of little curve
underneath is a marker for where note

423.06.text:
onsets are occurring so I can kind of see
where these things are occurring visually.

427.37.text:
So it's not very obvious in
the orange waveform, and then I have

430.55.text:
a form of spectrogram underneath that
also helps me decide on the alignment.

436.21.text: So it's kind of a semi-automated process.

438.82.text:
So there are ways of doing it fully
automated, but you'll get errors and for

443.61.text:
visual and audio alignment you
don't need to be too accurate.

446.42.text:
But in general I work on more
highly accurate alignment for

453.93.text: So this is the kinda map between

457.54.text:
time in the score which is the pinkish
color to time in the recording in red.

463.00.text:
And so this is kind of an example
of how the score is marked up.

465.80.text:
So what I do is in the score I just
do the number of quarter notes since

469.46.text:
the beginning of the piece, so it's
just the continuous sequence of numbers.

473.86.text:
It just counts how many quarter
note since beginning in the piece.

478.23.text:
the score gets labeled with a time
stamp in terms of quarter notes.

481.97.text: So I don't put real time in there.

484.32.text: That's cut in the table of the time map.

489.28.text:
So let me see then in the score
I prepare it, it's an SVG image.

497.84.text:
And for every graphical objects that I
need to highlight I wrap it in a G element

503.38.text:
which has in this case note on dash 95 and
note on 96.

507.69.text:
That means turn on the note
that quarter note 96 and

510.40.text:
turn it off at, I mean turn it
on at 95 and turn it off at 96.

514.72.text: So then what happens, so the big, so

517.99.text:
all I have to do when I'm performing
is I put a little on tag and

523.96.text:
I have a css style for the SVG,
which turns it red if it has the on class.

528.62.text:
When it's time to turn off, I just remove
the on tag and it goes back to black.

536.93.text:
Some I'm kind of working on generalizing
the software that's used in the class.

540.19.text:
At the moment it only works on
HTML 5 elements of audio and

544.67.text:
video but eventually I want to also do
it for YouTube which is more complicated

550.29.text:
process because I can't access the time
as fast as I can with audio element.

556.03.text:
And some working eventually
to have a not so

560.03.text:
great working version of
the software up online already.

563.25.text:
So if you're interested,
I can give you updates, or

565.43.text: you can help me with it in the future.

568.53.text: So that's my part of the presentation.

571.73.text:
[APPLAUSE]
>> And if you have questions for Craig,

577.51.text:
there will be some time for
Q and A at the end of this.

584.60.text:
There's one more solution that we
stumbled upon for the Haydn course.

591.49.text:
Really something that people use
all the time, learning by doing.

596.24.text:
We still wanted students to have more
opportunities to learn about reading

601.10.text:
music without adding more videos,
and lectures and readings.

606.17.text: So we just created a series of problems.

608.63.text:
Very simple problems where
the student is asked,

612.42.text:
they're given a score and they're asked to
click on the highest pitch for example.

617.23.text:
They're not instructed what these
pitch things are or notes are,

622.70.text:
what are these dots and lines,
but they are given an audio clip.

635.68.text:
Which corresponds to
the notes that they see.

639.51.text:
And if they need extra
help there's a hint button

643.47.text:
which tells them that the ovals
correspond to pitches.

648.64.text:
Further, we have a piano gadget
which we've included in the course.

654.87.text:
Now this is a piano
that students can play.

658.22.text:
When they click on a note
they will hear a pitch and

662.16.text:
they will also see the corresponding
note on the staff.

666.41.text:
So I'll show you what
that looks like as well.

683.75.text:
So this kinda lets the student
experiment and figure out for

690.98.text:
Now we have Julio here to tell us a little
bit about how he wrote the code for

697.09.text:
>> So this is actually a fairly simple, it
seems really complicated but really isn't.

705.06.text:
It was built as part of a hack-a-thon that
we were doing when js input first came out

710.88.text:
on edX which is actually quite a bit long
time ago, one and a half years now but,

715.56.text:
and so, we were just trying to play
with what js input could do and so

719.38.text:
I did this and another even simpler
one but this is really all it is.

723.56.text:
It's just joining three
different JavaScript

727.92.text:
libraries Raphael is just SVG
as it says there canvas drawing.

732.51.text:
Vex flow is to draw the little
staff with the note depending on

737.48.text: what input you give it and

739.11.text:
qwerty Hancock is an incredibly well-named
little to the piano is actually that one.

744.83.text:
And that just uses the JavaScript
audio library to generate audio waves.

751.41.text:
So in this case I think I'm using
a saw tooth wave for those things.

755.22.text:
Yeah and
that's where the code is available there.

757.97.text:
Including a bunch of other
stuff from us for js inputs.

771.61.text:
Now we have another course that had
a strange notation that students

776.29.text:
needed to learn how to translate
into something they can understand.

781.50.text:
And we have Kenny to talk to us
about taking deeper, thank you.

791.68.text:
>> Okay, so Digging Deeper is a sequence
of courses on medieval manuscripts.

799.83.text:
It was created by Professor Elaine
Treharne at Stanford collaborating with

804.19.text:
librarians at
Cambridge University Library and

808.10.text:
Stanford University Library and
also faculty at Cambridge.

811.56.text:
And the motivation for
this course is that a lot of

816.77.text:
manuscript material is out there in
some form, much of this being digitized.

820.44.text:
People can see medieval manuscripts but
they have no way to dig deeper

825.59.text:
as it were to find out what
the heck this stuff actually means.

829.33.text:
And the professor is very
invested in opening access.

834.11.text:
I mean manuscripts are our best
window into the medieval world,

837.60.text: this thousand year period of history.

839.92.text: There's a lot that you can get but

842.68.text:
you need to be able to get into
the manuscripts a little bit.

845.92.text: So how do you do that?

848.31.text:
The main challenge is to teach close
analysis of medieval handwriting and

854.02.text:
that is not a trivial challenge in
an online environment or anywhere.

861.36.text:
This medieval handwriting
is actually not bad.

866.27.text:
This is actually English,
this is Latin, but this is English, but

869.61.text:
it's really hard to read and
in order for learners

874.59.text:
to make substantial progress in this,
they have to get into this in some way.

880.48.text:
So what to do,
the first solution is the sort of easy or

885.88.text:
basic solution, which is to give people
a deep background on Medieval Culture.

891.72.text:
And we did this basically with videos and
multiple choice assessments.

896.09.text:
So basically, Elaine would talk about
where manuscripts were produced, why

902.80.text:
they were produced, how a scholar begins
to look at them, the materials used.

907.36.text: So there be a video and

908.94.text:
then some multiple choice to show that
you have paid attention to the video.

913.65.text:
And you can get a certain
distance with that.

917.32.text:
Here is a manuscript,
I know nothing about it.

921.52.text:
But I know what paper looks like, papyrus
looks like and what parchment looks like

926.68.text:
and I know that these are associate
with particular periods,

929.79.text:
with specific levels of affluence,
with specific historical events.

934.94.text:
Okay, so I can get a little
bit further into these texts.

938.65.text:
But the difficult problem remains
that you have to tackle paleography,

946.00.text:
the study of handwriting, and
again this is a serious Hurdle.

952.39.text:
Traditionally you'll get a book like this,
Introduction to Manuscripts Studies.

958.62.text:
And you'll sit with a world expert in
special collections for about five

963.68.text:
years going through manuscripts and
transcribing them with paper and pencil.

969.88.text:
So that's a little hard
to replicate in a MOOC.

975.60.text:
So what we did was,
Elaine made a video in which she

980.49.text:
basically had a text from
special collections, a pencil,

985.89.text:
and she showed this is how medievalist
actually learned to do what they do.

992.39.text:
They sit down,
they look at a manuscript and

995.01.text:
they transcribe it by a set of rules
that medievalists have come up with.

999.88.text:
And Elaine said,
we have to make this work online.

1006.20.text:
I think this is the best thing that came
out of this course in a lot of ways.

1011.04.text:
My response to the instructional
designer was, that's a terrible idea.

1015.62.text:
We shouldn't even touch this because,
first of all,

1021.05.text:
we don't have really
a good way to assess this.

1023.81.text:
We didn't come up with
a way that we'd check

1027.12.text:
that you were doing this
in any way correctly.

1030.76.text:
Also, I said this all very
politely obviously, but

1034.69.text:
I said,
why would anyone want to do that anymore?

1036.80.text: This is from an age when people had to,

1039.74.text:
you go to the library at York and
the only way that other medievalists

1044.34.text:
are gonna know what you thought is you
transcribe it correctly with your pencil.

1049.05.text:
But you can take a picture
with your iPhone now.

1051.63.text:
You don't need to do this anymore and
Elaine said, if you don't learn this,

1056.50.text:
you'll never learn what
you're looking at at all.

1062.78.text:
So the first version of this was
we have a page of a manuscript for

1066.78.text:
people to look at, and we have a text box,
and we give them certain rules for

1073.71.text:
So it's very imperfect in that many, many,
many, many, many medieval manuscripts

1080.30.text:
contain letters that no longer exist and
punctuation that no longer exists.

1087.54.text:
Also, there are things that you can do
on paper more easily, like underline,

1091.74.text:
that we didn't have
a good option with here.

1094.16.text: So we had good responses from people.

1096.64.text:
This is what it looks like when
somebody actually puts something in and

1100.15.text: this is the attempt to replicate it.

1102.35.text:
We could give a special character bank
here for people to copy and paste but

1107.14.text:
still we felt like this was a pretty
imperfect way of tackling the problem and

1111.93.text:
we wanted to bring people a lot closer to
what the manuscripts were actually saying.

1116.39.text:
And we could only do that with
the help of Julio, again.

1121.95.text:
>> All right, so I found online
that there's actually an initiative

1127.05.text:
by medievalists, something called MUFI, or
M-U-F-I, Medieval Unicode Font Initiative.

1135.02.text:
So there's this bank of Unicode
characters that are sort of left open for

1141.32.text:
do other things with that really don't
have anything specific to be used for.

1147.64.text:
And so there are special fonts, including
one that I ended up using for this,

1152.15.text:
which I guess is not on this screen but
you'll see it in the next slide.

1155.81.text:
That actually used those
Unicode characters and

1159.27.text:
mapped them to specific
medieval characters.

1162.99.text:
And so all I ended up doing was basically
building a little mini text editor,

1168.76.text:
kind of, using the same
functions as Google Docs uses.

1172.10.text:
Just JavaScript functions that detect
keystrokes for bolding and underlining,

1178.23.text:
And also just insert characters and change
sort of the color and size of characters.

1186.84.text:
So a lot of it I think was actually
built on the X block hackathon.

1193.47.text:
Yeah, let me know if anybody needs or
wants more information on how these work.

1200.81.text:
[LAUGH] Some pretty good
stuff comes out of those.

1205.93.text:
what we got to implement in the second
course was a new transcription tool.

1210.93.text:
And so you see again,
we have a page of medieval manuscript and

1216.74.text: down here is where you can input stuff.

1220.44.text:
And magically,
this meaning from the humanities,

1223.77.text:
magically you now have all these
characters that you didn't have before and

1228.60.text:
you've maybe never seen
represented on a computer screen.

1233.47.text: Now you can put any of them in.

1237.00.text:
So you have like all these
weirdo bits of punctuation,

1240.50.text:
you have that which is the T-H sound,
and also to represent,

1244.45.text:
it's called lideo or
notabilis, like a big letter.

1247.87.text: You can make the letter big.

1250.39.text:
And you can make it colored,
the colors were significant too.

1253.37.text:
So we thought that this was a huge
win when we had a really good

1258.09.text:
reaction from the community
around the course about this.

1265.16.text:
And we also just had a lot of
success with the palaeography

1270.50.text:
exercises even though they
were really difficult.

1275.42.text:
So here, orange and
yellow are course one and

1280.85.text: green and brown are course two.

1285.44.text: There's the usual sort of big drop-off,

1287.36.text:
but the overall attrition
we had was pretty good.

1291.84.text:
Completion rates were around 25% for
both courses.

1294.39.text:
And what was really significant
to me was that orange, here,

1300.01.text:
this unit completion, is the bread and
butter part of the course.

1306.06.text: It's the stable part of the course.

1307.27.text:
It's the videos with
the main materials and

1309.94.text:
the multiple choice quizzes
which were pretty easy.

1314.38.text: And yellow is the paleography exercises.

1317.64.text:
So in Course 1, you can see that
after the first week, more people

1322.28.text:
are doing the paleography exercises than
are actually just watching the videos and

1326.65.text:
doing the multiple choice, than
are interacting with the core content.

1331.09.text:
So the much harder part of this is
what people were more drawn to.

1335.90.text:
And similarly in course two, this is where
we implemented the new paleography tool.

1343.90.text:
The paleography tool became more popular
than the core content of the course,

1348.80.text:
so this is clearly where people felt
they were really getting traction

1355.45.text: And so next steps with this, we sort of

1359.64.text:
squished courses one and
two into a franking course.

1364.57.text:
It was six weeks and five weeks, we're on
the quarter system, four sems, and so,

1370.23.text:
now we have a ten-week course
that has all the material and

1375.04.text:
we've implemented the new
paleography tool throughout.

1377.94.text:
We've run it on campus and
gotten good feedback on that so

1382.30.text:
we want to run this publicly and
add another course where paleography

1387.56.text:
will be the key aspect of it,
which will be Digging Deeper 3.

1392.31.text: So I think we have left some time for Q&A.

[INAUDIBLE] You mentioned
the completion rate is 25%.

1418.50.text: Is this is the completion rate for

they are established students in this-

So, we mostly stuck with

So, for example,

listen to the music, how many times do

outside of the platform was actually

That was not actually

there was no assessment attached to that?

1595.52.text:
>> That's right.
That one has no assessment attached to it.

1597.59.text:
I mean, it was used in some
of the assessments as like,
